We went for brunch after hearing many good things, but I think this would be another spot where I've enjoyed the food, but haven't found it to be so special or outstanding that I would go out of my way to return.Bodega sandwich: I enjoyed the biscuit, the eggs were fluffy, and the sauce was good too.  That said, the clear, overwhelming taste is the sausage, and it masks the other flavors a bit.  Personally, sausage is not my preferred breakfast or sandwich meat, but I still liked the sandwich overall.Pastrami and hash sandwich: this one fell a bit short; there was a lot of hash and next to no pastrami.  Pastrami is a heavy meat, but I could barely taste it over the hash.  I found myself picking out the hash and eating it separately in an attempt to balance the sandwich more and actually taste the pastrami.Duck meatball sub: a good sandwich, but not something  I'd care to order again.  The liver taste was stronger than I expected, so if you're not a  fan of liver, this won't be for you.Date and almond oatcake: this was the best item for me.  The salt from the buttery pastry nicely balanced out the sweet filling, and the texture felt light and slightly crunchy, almost like a biscuit.  Other pastries looked good too, so may be worth trying more of their bakery items.

Came for dinner.The hummus for appetizer was the best part of the meal. Texture perfectly, not too salty, strong (almost sweet) carrot and olive oil flavor - simply delicious. Volkornbrot toast was fresh - wish we had more though. No more smoked potato gnocchi by the time I got there for dinner but the cauliflower caramelle was very savory. The blueberry and chocolate desserts weren't bad but they weren't anything special either. Good service, even on a busy night.

I ordered the pastrami and hash and it had all the makings of a delicious looking sandwich. I mean look at the photos! However this thing dripped more oil than deep water horizon. And I'm not talking about a few drops here and there. I've had juicy burgers, so this isn't foreign to me.  No. I'm talking a sready drip of just pure unblotted grease falling onto the serving tray. If you have a cholesterol test within three months of eating here, don't do it!!

Came here for breakfast with a friend on a Monday morning. Really enjoyed it! Really awesome breakfast options that are guaranteed to suit your palate. I can't wait for the next opportunity to return!

I went to High Street on Hudson for a 12pm brunch on Labor Day, and it was delicious. I shared the pastrami and hash sandwich, the bodega sandwich and the fried potatoes. The fried potatoes were probably my favorite breakfast potatoes that I've had in a long time. Also, the garlic aioli was delicious. Both sandwiches hit the spot too. The pastrami one was a little more interesting taste wise. The disappointment was that by noon they had no pastries left except for cookies our server informed us, and they were also out of the biscuit that the bodega sandwich was supposed to be on. I'll definitely be back to try a pastry and eat breakfast here again!

came here for brunch w/ my friend, and there was about a 20 min wait.  not too bad, considering every other brunch place looked way worse.  i had the forager sandwich, and my friend had the beet cured salmon on bagel.  by noon, they already ran out of everything bagels.  :(  we also got a side of the fried potatoes, which was a good move.  my sandwich was good.  i asked for no cheese, but they still put cheese on it, but i was able to pick it off easily.  there were a ton of mushrooms and kale on it, so it was a bit messy to eat.  i like the condiments on the tables, and they made the sandwiches even more tasty.

Great lunch or breakfast option in the West Village.The turkey club is plenty big, served on the most delicious poppy seed potato roll.   Salads are decent size and baked goods are fresh and delicious.Comfortable spot for coffee and super nice service.
Horrible.  Horrible Service.  Food menu completely limited.  Never wasting our time here again.

Everything about High Street was stellar, from the food, ambiance, and service. Very fresh ingredience coupled with beautiful presentations. Beau, our server was informed about the options and ever gratuitous. The perfect culinary experience. Go. You won't be sorry.
Great food, beautiful venue, and Beau is the best server ever!! Their pastries are amazing. Our two meals there were the highlights of our trip to the city.

Amazing pastries (highly recommend starting w many-- selection varies by day). Lattes were 10/10-- probably the best in the neighborhood. Tried the pastrami bfast sandwich and one of the other bfast sandwiches-- both were excellent.My advice is to go with a group and share many different pastries so that you can try the whole selection

Absolutely delicious weekday breakfast spot! We had two of the breakfast sandwiches and were completely blown away by how delicious they were and how big the portions were. The interior design of the restaurant was wonderful with a perfect layout (grab and go coffee counter in the front, main dining area in the center, open kitchen in back, bathrooms with exterior sinks, etc). Our food was seriously incredible. My husband and I have a tradition of going to breakfast out every Friday morning before work and in the 75+ breakfasts we've had in / around NYC, this was easily one of the top 3. I would wholeheartedly recommend this place to anyone looking for an amazing breakfast. Can't wait to go back for lunch and dinner soon.

I went to High Street one morning because I heard great things about the bodega sandwich. And yes this sandwich is delicious and includes everything you want after a night of drinking but if only it was 50% bigger or cheaper. I loved the sandwich but honestly didn't feel it was worth the price. People around me ordered the lunch sandwiches, which were bigger and weren't that different in price. We did order a side of potatoes, which were also great but I'll always be wishing there was more of that sandwich to go around.

Small but modern place in a sweet neighborhood. The menu is limited but the breakfast sandwiches we enjoyed hit the spot.The coffee is STRONG enough to blow your top. The service was attentive and the food was delicious.The only drawback is the Sun peers in for those against the window with no shade relief in sight. It was HOT when we visited too.

Holy bejesus this place is delicious! We came here for lunch after walking the High Line on one of the hottest day in the city (idiots). In search for something cool and refreshing, I ordered the coldest thing on the menu - roasted turkey sandwich. GAH! Maybe it was the heat that made it taste so good, but I've been thinking about that sandwich ever since. It was so juicy and flavorful! It comes with a grilled pepper. Take a bite of the pepper and a bite of the sandwich at the same time. You won't be disappointed!

It is always exciting to find out some local restaurants brought their own food into the city of New York - so for this, thank you very much chef Kulp and chef Yin, thanks for bringing the phenomenal recreation of High Street on Market to west village.Even though each one of the three meals were served, I only got the opportunity to try out their brunch menu, which was already good enough. My friend and I split the seared mushroom sandwich and the chef's salad. If you are a burger fan, you would not want to skip the sandwich, especially considering the fact that High Street on Hudson had one of the better bread heartily prepared by Alex Bois. Scrambled egg tucked in the middle was soft enough that, when combined with the mushroom piece and cheese, completely melt in my mouth! Didn't remember but the second I realized, the sandwich was already gone! Chef's salad, on the other hand, hmm tasted really healthy...meat lovers you guys would not be satisfied...Forgot to order their renown bread, which was freshly baked every morning. The whole restaurant was really down-to-earth so nice to grab a seat inside or outside, even for a small glass of iced latte. However, the place could get extremely crowded during brunch times, as no brunch reservation is taken. Come early and enjoy some carbs, this is the type of place where you would like to load on calories yet not feel guilty.

West village never run out of great brunch spots. And nothing beats a quality outdoor brunch in the lovely and tranquil west village neighborhood. That brings us to the High Street on Hudson with exciting brunch options and a corner bar serving to-go bakeries! The phily spin-off provides all-day meals and all-day breads as they are baked throughout the day. My friend and I shared grilled mushroom sandwich (with scrambled eggs inside) and chef salad (roasted turkey, soft boiled eggs, feta and veggies). I loved the grilled mushroom sandwich - layers of goodies - two pieces of soft bread with a natural sweet note hugging the fluffy and cheesy scrambled egg and savory mushrooms! One bite, hmmmm, I'm happy inside out! Lastly the grilled pickled hot pepper nicely balances the luxuries taste of the sandwich.I also get the Buckwheat cherry bread to-go. It is so good that I can eat it on its own. Toasty crust with nutty taste, chewy inside with a consistent cherry aroma and little acidity. (I'm not a huge bread eater but this might change me.)I will def come back to try out other breads/brunch items!

The food was a hit or miss I found, I was not a huge fan of the sunflower risotto, made strictly from sunflower seeds and no grains. Deep fried broccoli was okay, the burrata was average, and the duck was pretty delicious though. The portions are pretty tiny and they recommend you get a few dishes at least. We waited for a seat for a 15-20 min even though there were open ones available (the restaurant was less than half full), and we had a reservation.

Came here Saturday with a friend for brunch and it was already crowded but luckily we got a table right away. I ordered the pastrami & hash and he ordered the forager (which has only veggies- kale and mushroom). I cut my sandwich in half and traded my half with his half so I can try the other one as well. I preferred the sandwich I got..guess since mine had meat in it at least. Not going to lie..was pretty good but a bit hard to eat... I grabbed the sandwich take a bite and everything inside slipped out..my hands got pretty oily.Was a bit disappointed with the portion... Each of the sandwiches were $13 but very small! I ate it pretty quickly and was still hungry afterwards. I think I should've waited 20 more minutes to get something off the lunch menu instead...those sandwiches looked bigger

This week's fashionplate takes place at Philly offshoot High Street on Hudson.  Went here for a catch up dinner on a Sunday night.  The restaurant was not very full and the tables are close together.  I decided to wear our super comfy Naomi polka dot maxi skirt.  We had some nice rose to keep the weekend vibe flowing. We then proceeded to split a few things which we all know by now is my signature move.  We started with the crispy broccoli which was fried and Asian inspired.  This was interesting but we didn't love the execution. They then brought out the baked potatoes which we really liked and was made with vegan sour cream.  The mushrooms was our least favorite dish.  It was too pungent and vinegary, and we both adore mushrooms usually.  The long island duck was great, one of our top 10 duck dishes.  All in all it is a creative and fun menu although it was a mixed bag with us loving two of the dishes while the other two were meh.  I would try brunch or lunch however.

Location: The place is less approachable for someone who depends on subway for day to day life.But I went for it any way because I heard all the good news for their bakeries.The place is actually a cafe with an extra space for bakeries.Inside, the decoration is pretty cozy.Bakery: had their cookies, croissants! I cannot tell you how great those are. Cookies are less sweet but very comfortable for me to eat another one. Croissants are immersed with flavors.!Price: and it's not expensive at all .comeenjoyandhave your sweet teeth satisfied.

Cute place on corner of Hudson.  Very cozy seating with wood chairs that make you want to be picky about where you sit.  Seeing fresh bread come out of the oven and dropped right for sale was awesome. We visited for breakfast on the weekend. My bagel with cream cheese was excellent but extremely heavy with cream cheese that melted into a pool on my plate and felt unhealthy. My friend got the breakfast sandwich that she loved but was mystified by the pepper it came with. We would have loved to ask about it but our server was sporadic. He also missed one of our sides and we decided not to bother. He also took 20 minutes to bring us extra napkins which we had by that point already gotten from the front take out area. Tighten up the service and this place is a home run.

The good: My partner ordered the bodega breakfast sandwich and really enjoyed it. The one bite I had was delicious. I ordered the ginger yogurt, which was light, flavorful, and delicious as well.The bad: The prices reflected on the menu did not match what we were charged. With two of four items, the price on our bill was higher than that on the menu. While the difference was not enormous, this is just annoying. Also, wasn't a fan of the potato salad.The ugly: Came all the way from Brooklyn for the red eye danish only to find that it wasn't available. Not sure if it's been taken off the menu forever (High St, is this so?) or only temporarily. Regardless, this was a huge disappointment.4 stars because of the incorrect menu prices and disappointment over red eye danish. Would return for a breakfast sandwich (they looked amazing) and/or pastries.

An over-priced sandwich shop.  One of my teenage grandsons noted after having their "Spicy Gabagool" that it was "pretty much like Subway's 'Spicy Italian' except that the bread is better". No question about it, the breads are good here but worth paying $14.00 for a 10 " salami, cheese and shredded lettuce hero? The " Footlong Spicy Italian", by the way, costs $5.50.

One of the best tasting menus I've had in awhile along with a great wine pairing to boot. Every dish with every wine pairing was delicious. Only dish that was not perfection was the happy beef that was a bit too salty for my taste. Otherwise it was all superb. If you're a first timer, skip the menu and just go for the tasting menu. You'll get a real feel of what this restaurant is all about!

Yes, yes, and yes.  This is exactly what a restaurant should be.  Inventive dishes, rustic decor, and excellent service.  I have been going to Fork, their original spot in Philadelphia, for many years.  I had very high expectations, and they were certainly exceeded here at High.  We had the tasting menu, which was unique, flavorful, and surprisingly a great value.  For $65, we had approximately seven courses, each of which was a sizable portion.  The only item on the menu that was not absolutely perfect, was the steak, which was perfectly cooked but slightly over salted.  The gnocchi were unreal, I will be having dreams about them.  This place is a slam dunk and I am eager to try new additions to the menu as the seasons change.

Can only speak for dinner here, and it was delicious!It's a pretty causal place, as the main focus is breakfast and lunch, so it didn't have the real dinner vibe, so to speak, a lot of the newer restaurants have.  That didn't take away from our experience, but it probably would have been nice to have a drink at the bar before dinner, except there's no bar here...that is truly missing.As for the food, I'm not a huge bread eater, but you need to throw that idea out the window when you dine here as they're all about the bread.  And their amazing spreads to go with it.  The various hummus dishes they brought out with their breads were fantastic and worth every single carb we consumed.We ordered from the 'leave it to us' menu and we're glad we did...delicious!  This is where we had a bunch of their hummus and the pasta dishes were real stand outs for us.  Nice portions, too, not tiny tasting portions.Wine list is small, but you can find something to suit your taste and their prices are so affordable.I'm taking off a star due to the limited wine list and lack of a bar, but all in all, a very yummy night out and looking forward to trying their breakfast & lunch!

Rather disappointed. Not much variety on the menu and it just wasn't to my liking. On the plus side the atmosphere is nice and the staff was friendly. I am sure others think it is good, but I think it is overpriced for what it is...

Really creative dishes and presentation! I came for a "snack" with a friend and we shared 4 plates. I really recommend the mushrooms and carrot spread with the vollkornbrot. Portions are definitely on the smaller side but since I only came for snack it was ok. I definitely want to come back to try their chicken for two!

Solid 4.5I would love to go here all the time if I wasn't sure I'd be in for a 2-hour wait.  It's comfortable, delicious food that doesn't come off as high end but is all amazing quality and made in house.  I went for brunch and everything on the menu looked amazing!  The egg sandwiches are some of the best I've had, and the fact that High Street on Hudson opened with brunch as its first meals makes you sure it wasn't an afterthought.  Great location, great food - highly recommend!

Food :BuccatiniBurrataGnocchiGood choices on a chilly Thursday night. Decor. Cool yes, but nothing extraordinary. There is a stand selling food in the cramped space.Experience. liked the vibe but it is very packed and we were seated close the entrance with wind blowing in when guests were coming inside.Drinks. Don't remember, must have been average.Overall had high expectations but was let down. Maybe I didn't get the concept.
i had one of the best breakfast sandwiches ever here. and the waiter kept calling me sweetie. what else can a girl ask for from life.

Came here for lunch with a friend and we both ordered the turkey sandwich, and honestly it was great. The bread was perfect, not too soft, not too hard and very fresh. The turkey wasn't dry, there was lettuce, tomato and some mayo on it.I asked our very friendly server if the restaurant had honey mustard, she said no then later came back and said she asked the kitchen and they told her that they have a "maple mustard". I gave it a try, and it was delicious. (I love sauces, especially sweet ones)The potato salad wasn't really my thing, although my friend liked it. The restaurant itself is very nice, I love the set up. The hostess was very friendly and actually allowed us to wait for the specific table that we wanted, as the people occupying it were about to head out. I'll definitely return to try their pastrami on rye.

I'm definitely missing something and I think it's probably the experience here at meals other than dinner. When Food and Wine magazine named them the top restaurant in NYC this past week, we grabbed an immediate reservation. Given this top prize, I had high expectations. The space is nice...casual and cafe-like but slightly cramped for the two-tops along the wall. Service was good. The menu was simple and I was excited to try it given focused menus with sharing plates are my jam. Here's a synopsis of the food we tried: Crispy broccoli - tempura broccoli with a tangy kimchi-like dressing. It was good. But you could fry a piece of cardboard and it'd be tasty. Burrata - very small portion but good Burrata. The prettiness of the dish outweighed the tastiness. Mushrooms - in the top two...an assortment of mushrooms in a bit of a creamy sauce. This dish would've been great with a side of crostini. But alas, we ate them solo. Bucatini - very good dish, simple and fresh. It's considered a full portion but it's an appetizer size. For $28. Good but I would not consider it worth the price. Duck - great dish...smokey and savory flavor and not too fatty. This would also not be considered an entree size dish as there were four small pieces of duck. As for drinks, I sampled both a cocktail and a glass of wine. Cocktail was meh...it wasn't complex at all and tasted like lemonade. The red wine list by the glass was primarily Long Island (which I don't care for) with only two choices outside of there...I went with a California cab which was decent but not great, especially not for $16/glass. Our bill was $200 without tip, and I was still slightly hungry when I got home. I'm still trying to figure out F&W's award. HSonH was solid but by no means great in comparison to others in this giant city of the N-Y-C.

After we finished dinner here, we had to go somewhere else to get an actual meal.Service: 5 star. Truly professional level staff. Food: The chicken was perfectly fine, if it cost $20 for a serving for 1 I would rave about it. It costs $52 for a serving for 1 however and then they lie and claim it will feed 4. The rest of the food is empty calories and fiber. Over-sauced pastas and lettuce essentially round out the menu and cost $15 to $30 per order for tiny 4 morsel tasting plates. Drinks: Poorly conceived. A teenager was locked out of the house with his parents garden and their patio bar. The result? Cheap liquor poured over "Spring" veggie flavors. I ended up asking them to just leave everything out and give me vodka on the rocks. Ambiance: It's a sandwich shop with tables and an open kitchen. Pleasant. Booths were comfortable and spacious and tables were properly spaced. I can find no fault with the restaurant here. Bit loud actually, no music but something about the place made the crowd noise echo. It was pretty hard to hear my table. Value: The only reason this place received a positive review from the NYT is because the NYT wasn't paying for their food. Simply nonsense, there is no reason to ever dine here. $90 per person for 2 (bad) drinks, about 2 oz of chicken per person, and a couple morsels of appetizer. Absurd, even for meat packing. You would be better served at a restaurant like Fedora. You would pay just as much but at least you would receive a special experience and extraordinary flavors for your investment. To be fair, my experience was with the dinner menu only. Other reviews seem to reflect that the lunch menu is reasonably priced and edible. I wish I had read the dinner menu reviews before I went here. Never again. And the two dollar sign rating on Yelp? This restaurant straight up lies.

High Street on Hudson is known for their baked goods and just moved to NYC territory to claim their fame. While the baked goods taste good, I feel it is priced higher than usual. The to-go counter is a little cramped and uncomfortable, so it's best to really take it out and eat on the run. The restaurant looks like a cafe space, no-frills and they are still ironing out pretty much everything.

This place is my favorite place in all of North America! Haha jk, but it's damn close. I was first introduced to their pastries at Rival Bros. in Philly. I then tracked down High Street on Market to stock up on pastries since my trip to Philly was coming to an end. I was literally heartbroken and contemplating another trip to Philly just for High Street when I found out about their NYC location and man, I cannot rave enough about it!! Their red eye danish is all my dreams come true, the Bodega (which they don't have in Philly) is one of the best breakfast sandwiches I have ever had, their (Rival Bros.) coffee, their cauliflower side, their ginger yogurt, and literally everything else I have ever ordered in this place, is perfection. Thank you so so much for opening a Manhattan location; I am obsessed with you guys!!! One con: they're not open 24/7.

Well, yes breakfast is the most important meal of the day... And for some of us we can't do with out it. I was more than blessed to stumble upon this joint after a nice run on the hudson river. I can tell you that their service and decor is a direct hit, Their staff is knowdleagble and friendly. Now the food has a very boutique presentation. their menu changes seasonally, and they have a few original items. I tried their Salmon Bagel, which is baked in house! and Also their Pork Sandwich, The fact that the bake all their bread in-house daily is just wonderful, Taking the time to craft such a menu really makes them unique i hope more people are aware of the commitment and belief they stand for. I wish more places could operate like this regularly, on my next trip to manhattan, ill be there, Thank you HS CHEERS
We ate very good house made bagels and delicious granola. It is are very nice place with excellent service. We enjoyed our breakfast.
This place was very cramped but the bagels were delicious! The coffee was nice and strong!

Sorry, but I honestly think this place is overrated.  I have been here twice and both times I thought our meal was average at best.  Atmosphere was boring and service was fine.  Overall, I wouldn't make an effort to return.

Would love to learn more about the chef because we were blown away by EVERY dish. The very inventive combo of flavors really reminded me of Yottam Ottolenghi's dishes. The squid ink pasta was tender, tangy, crunchy, with very interesting flavors. And lobster ?discs? Not sure what they were but they were a great addition. And visually stunning! The scallions also went so well with this dish.Mushrooms with black, wild rice was also a great combination of chewy, nutty, and tangy. Funnily enough, the bread was not my thing. I really love bread that's fresh baked, hot, crusty (or not) and tender on the inside...and that's not the type of bread that's here. Either way, I can't wait for whoever the chef is to come up with more insanely creative and tasty dishes for us.

Stopped in today after a local highly recommended it to us! We shared the pastrami sandwich, most amazing flavors ever. We also got a side of cauliflower, asparagus and potatoes. All were unreal! Best tasting lunch! The staff was super friendly and the service was great!

Feel like the place should only be 3.5 star, but i rounded up. Came here for dinner and we thought the food was good but not amazing. All the plates were innovative and the presentation was very nice. However, the portions are small. The dishes are meant to be shared but i thought they were pricey for just shared plates. There weren't that many choices for dinner either We ordered 7 dishes between the 3 of us and that was 70% of the menu. We liked the bucatini dish and the duck dish was good too. Dessert was bleh. I got the melted chocolate with Japanese cheesecake. The decor was trendy. Open kitchen and huge windows. The noise level is loud. I had a hard time hearing my friends. Make sure u make reservations because by the time we left at 9pm there was a line waiting. Read a lot of good reviews about this place. Maybe breakfast and brunch is better than dinner.

One of the worst meals I've ever had.    We started off with fried broccoli. Good texture but zero taste, but the sauce with it tasted really bad.    Then we had asparagus, they were ok but they came with trout, egg custard and pickles - ew, really over complicated and bad.    Then we ordered the Atlantic Bream to share, firstly the portion was tiny which was unexpected as it was for two.  The fish wasn't cooked properly and smelt awful, we had one mouthful and left it all.  The food tasted the same coming up later that night as it had going in, that's never a good sign.    Nice decor and friendly good service.
The best panzanella salad I've ever had. Lovely service, great atmosphere. Pricey. If you want to treat yourself, go splurge at High Street.

wish I read more of the reviews before coming here for dinner the other night. Saw some amazing stuff in the yelp photos but did not realize they were only available for lunch. Dinner menu was kind of slim pickin's and they did not have specials.  Since we were not going to get the chicken dish for $52, we had even less choices. I would not have an issue with the prices of the food here if the portions were not so miniscule,  the burrata really should have been called "a small salad with a silver dollar size (and that is me being generous with the description)piece of cheese that appeared to have been sliced in half! "  I am not sure how it may ruin their profit margine on this particular dish to just give the customer a normal size portion of burrata??!! The daily bread was just ok for a place known for their bread according to another reviewer, two of the spreads were burned smears on a wooden board and tasted very similar to each other.  The smoked eel was tasty, again not big and has mostly other ingredients that were not the eel.  The pasta dish was delicious, and the most generously portioned out of everything we got, still left us wanting just a little more for the price that it is.  I definitely want to come back to try their brunch and lunch, but will not return for dinner unless I am really not hungry.

The review is for a Friday lunch, which could not have been better. We waited all of one minute for a table to clear. The pastrami sandwich is the alternative to Katz's: Thick sliced, on superior bread, great mouth feel. I am not saying it's better, but it is a different, yet equally satisfying experience in a more comfortable, less touristy restaurant. The roast pork sandwich with aged provolone and greens was a bit different from the Philly original. The meat was not sopping with gravy, and the cheese had an extra layer of complexity and funk. It's good sandwich, it just pales in comparison to the pastrami. On the side of the pork, a roasted banana pepper added a bit of zing. More zing can come from the chow chow on your table, but that didn't go with what we ordered. For a side we ordered a mix of giardinera, cauliflower and grilled asparagus. The cauliflower was the prize pick. No room for dessert.
Amazing food, great location and fast service.  Must visit spot for Breakfast, lunch or dinner.  Stop off and walk the Highline.

Had a great weekday lunch here. No wait for a table, though the menu is extremely limited. I shared a bowl of three sides (beets, cauliflower and mushrooms) and it was delicious. I then split the pastrami sandwich, which was flavorful and not too fatty, and I loved the beet-dyed hard deviled egg it came with. Finally, I had a molasses cake and mini doughnut to go from the bakery. Really high quality, natural products here! Will definitely return for brunch when I'm up for the wait.Edit 6/2018: Had the turkey sandwich and little gem sandwich this time around, and while everything was delicious, I did think the portions were a bit small for the price.

3.5 rounding down to a 3. Yes, High Street is better known for brunch / lunch and its breads and sandwiches, but it is not memorable as a dinner joint, especially considering its price point.The decor is extremely dim - to the point where I struggled to see what my food looked like, so definitely a good spot for a self-conscious first date if that's what you are striving for here... Service was very friendly and homely, giving educated advice on food orders and portion sizes.Some of the dishes were excellent, but others suffer from the traditional New American curse of just putting a bunch of "interesting" ingredients onto the plate together and praying it works. We ordered:- Vollkornbrot (4/5): yes, the bread is absolutely the best part about High Street. The vollkornbrot is excellent, filled with strong dark rye aroma and dipped in delicious rutabaga hummus. Just wish there were more than 4 tiny pieces that came with a $12 order.- Anadama (5/5): best thing on the menu. Eel and radish paired with sweet tomatoes on top of a slightly sweet molasses bread. It just works. But again, $16 for one small tartine?- Tripe diavola (3/5): not quite spicy and sounded more interesting on paper than it did in taste. Just your standard tripe dish without much to make it too interesting.- Grilled squid (3/5): five stars for the plating - the dish is pretty as a picture, but again, nothing to write home about. Carrots add a nice crunch I suppose? But the squid itself is just nicely cooked, perhaps on the dryer side.- Cauliflower caramelle (4.5/5): High Street does carbs the best. These little stuffed pastas are absolutely fantastic, swimming in delicious rosemary and buttermilk that reminds you of an elevated version of the traditional Italian sage and butter preparation. Delicious, but very small portion size - have I mentioned that before? Among the four of us we probably got two small caramelle each. Did I also mention this costs $24?- Seaweed bucatini (4/5): again, carbs shine here and this is another winner. Comes with nice crab lumps and topped with scallions to give it almost an Asian inspiration. Portion is a bit more generous as well (i.e. we maybe could have three bites instead of two).- Both the entrees (duck and beef) were good but absolutely standard modern American preparations (i.e. forgettable). I'd double up on the pasta.- Saving graces would be that the desserts are actually extremely interesting. We had a carrot cake that was perfectly baked and slightly crispy on the outside and a little moist on the inside, served with a scoop of slightly salty bourbon ice cream that complemented the flavors perfectly. The salted caramel and chocolate budino was also excellent, but runs the risk of being slightly too salty than sweet.All in all, I'd come back to High Street for dinner if it was half the price and put its breads and pastas - what it is really good at - much more front and center. But for now, just ok.
Breads are excellent.  Had them at a wine charity yesterday and looking forward to visiting the hudson street location.

While visiting New York, many people told me about a cafe spot that originated from Philadelphia and is killing it in the meat packing district. I heard they made great sandwiches and thats exactly what I came in for. The interior gave off a upscale/relax feel for lunch.I ended up ordering their take on a pastrami sandwich while my girlfriend chose the duck meatballs sub. Both our meals were amazing! I really enjoyed her sub because the toasted bread and the flavor coming out of each duckball. These sandwiches are priced pretty high but they are quite filling. I left stuffed and at the end of the day, I want my meal to do that. For my sandwich, they had big thick cuts of pastrami and gooey cheese falling off the side. Overall, just really elevated flavors in each meal. I would 100% come back when Im back in NYC. Service was awesome and made sure we were enjoying all meals. 5 out of 5 in my opinion. They created unique sandwiches with great taste and big portions. I could not ask for more!

We had a great meal at High Street and whoever is working in the kitchen knows how to prepare interesting and amazing dishes.  The cauliflower pasta and the chicken were excellent, as was the crispy broccoli.  The experience -- including service, menu selection and price were problematic at best.  To begin with the menu was tough to figure out.  There is one list to choose from.  Some of the items are small dishes, others medium or large.  There is on indication as to what is small or large.  Most restaurants separate those items and list them on different pages or with lines between the two groups.  Here the demarcation is fuzzy.  You have to try to figure this out through the price of each item.With regard to price High Street is high.  A three pound chicken was $52.  A prima piatti plate of pasta was $24, the broccoli and bread plates are $11.  A glass of Syrah was $15.  These are high prices for the Village and high prices given the quantity and standard of service and casual nature of the restaurant.

Really busy, but great brunch spot.We stopped by as a party of 2 around 11:15 on a Saturday morning, and we had to wait about half an hour before being seated. We waited by the bakery in the front and had a citrus doughnut and crepe cake to start, both of which were solid, particularly the latter. For our meal, we split the hickory town and the bodega sandwiches, both of which were very good. I thought the hickory town in particular was really good, the cheddar and mayo going very well with the meat, while the bread on both sandwiches was also great. The old bay potatoes were also very good, lightly fried without being overcooked. I'd definitely come back to try some of the other dishes or for other meals.

Dinner review.  Totally underwhelmed and can't understand the hype in a city with countless restaurants that deliver on a much higher level.  Portions are comically small for a menu that is meant to be 'shared', and the food is mostly forgettable.  Got some bread to start as this is one of their 'things'.  I love good hearty, dense, nutty bread, but ultimately, it is just bread.  I don't need to hear about the German origins of our choice or any other backstory for that matter.  Get over it.  What I would like is more than 4 tiny slices of toast (I do mean tiny) for our $11 bread course.  A bad omen for the rest of the meal.The remainder of the courses followed a similar pattern.  The burrata, risotto, pike, beef...all well executed but unexciting and portioned in a manner that was impossible to share.  I'm not looking to be stuffed, but I should expect more than a single taste of a 'shared' course.  The broccoli was fine, it's broccoli after all.  The buccatini was the one standout.  Delicious and appropriately sized.  Finished with two tiny pieces of unremarkable cheese and oat ice cream on top of oats in a blueberry compote of sorts.  Our mistake for not thinking it through prior to ordering, but oat ice cream on a bed of oats?  virtually inedible unless you're a horse I suppose.Solid cortado and all American wine list from small producers with an Old World style, which is laudable, but limiting.  Head to Rebelle, Estela, Pearl and Ash or down the street to Barbuto which are just a few of the many restaurants which pull off this style of restaurant in a far, far superior way.

Great pastries!! However, breakfast sandwiches are too salty for me.Tried 3 items from breakfast menu and had to drink a lot of water after eating, too heavy for breakfast, or just my diet habit? $13.00 for a sandwich.Seems like the hot spot that do not take reservation, well,, not convinced they are that good worthy of 1 hour wait for brunch, but would like to go back and try it sometime.

This review is for dinner only...Was here last week with two girlfriends. Started with some great Rose by the window ledge, then headed to our table for dinner.With the all the hype surrounding this place, the three of us were completely unimpressed. We ordered the following:Daily Bread plate - horrible and two out of three of the spreads were inedibleBurrata - I didnt actually see any burrata, but I assume it was there. Very strange dishCauliflower Caramelle - this was the best dish by far! Really delicious. Problem was, caramelle are pretty small and thin pieces of pasta. I believe there were about 6 on the plate. So disappointing!Crispy broccoli - totally not exciting and completely forgettable, even though the waitress raved about it.Our biggest problem were the portion sizes. When the waiter brought the "deconstructed carrot cake", I literally said out loud, "are you f**ing kidding me?!". After I apologized for my profanity we literally had to laugh at this point. It was about three spoonfuls of cake and a tiny scoop of ice cream.Came to $80 each, and afterwards we went for pizza....sigh.

KenScale: 8.0/10There are not many all-day restaurants in New York City; it takes certain amount of courage and dedication to operate a place in this hectic, high-rent city. Yes, there have been some restaurants notable for offering some amazing breakfast and/or lunch options, but mostly the focus of most restaurants in Big Apple still lies in dinner. Chef Eli Kulp and his business partner Ellen Yin came all the way from Philadelphia to change that with a New York outpost of their highly acclaimed High Street restaurant. In the morning, the restaurant is a bakery serving pastries; at lunch, it serves a variety of sandwich options; for dinner, it becomes a full-fledged restaurant incorporating many of the breads baked in the morning. That kind of versatility is a scarce asset in New York dining scene, and I was certainly intrigued to see what kind of food the kitchen was delivering. Overall, I had a very pleasant dining experience on my recent weekend dinner. There is nothing fancy about the food at High Street, but you can tell that a lot of thoughts and preparations have been devoted to it. There are a handful of toast menus, and I enjoyed the one with smoked eel, spicy radish and parsley that had a lot of delightfulness to each bite. Among a small list of pasta dishes, don't skip seaweed bucatini that comes with nduja, mussels, bread crumb and lobster bottarga. It was a wonderful (and beautifully plated) pasta dish that has great balance of flavor; I initially wished the noodle were a little bit more firm, but over time, the softer texture of noodle started to gel really well with the other elements of the dish. For the entrees, I felt the Long Island duck was a bit more successful than grilled arctic char. Arctic char, which came with crispy potato, mustard greens, pickled gribiche and black olive, came away a little too aggressive in seasoning, although the fish itself was very nicely cooked. On the other hand, duck was cooked to near perfection for absolutely juicy, tender texture, and worked harmoniously with soured oats and grains, charred leek and turnip that accompanied it. For dessert, we had roasted milk chocolate with Japanese cheesecake, preserved lemon and cocoa bean, a solid but not particularly memorable dish.The restaurant has a somewhat concise menu of wine (many of them from the nearby New York area) and beer and I wish they could've really ramped up their wine selection to make the dinner even more memorable. Getting a reservation wasn't particularly challenging, but the restaurant has been getting a lot of buzz lately and the dining space is not particularly large, so make sure to book in advance if possible. I really liked the inviting vibe of the dining space that makes it well-suited for the type of all-day neighborhood restaurant that it strives to be. Well, there is at least one Philly import that has made a successful move to New York; I'm curious to see if other Philly restaurateurs and chefs will follow the path of chef Kulp. Certainly, High Street on Hudson is the type of restaurant that is so reliable as to make it a place that you would want to visit again.

If you're going to break your ban on carbs, this is the place to do it! Really cute spot and great food - we ordered the forager sandwich and the pastrami sandwich - both were Divine. I also sampled the sourdough bread and it was out of this world. Got there on the early side and by the time I left (11:30) there was a long wait for tables - so be prepared.

Come here for a cheap brunch (under $20). My 2 girlfriends and I came on a Saturday noon and the wait was about 45 minutes to an hour. The location of the restaurant is great. It's steps away from the Hudson River so walk along there while you wait. It's also close to the Whitney Museum, the Standard and the High Line for a lazy afternoon, post-brunch stroll. The restaurant is rustic and cafe like. There's an open kitchen which adds to the authenticity. I got the $16 "meatpacker" (didn't want to dirty my hands for the sandwiches) which is different from your traditional eggs and hash dish. It didn't leave me super stuffed like brunch usually does or hungry after. The potatoes it came with were the bomb. My 2 friends both got the pastrami sandwich. I tried some of it and it was decent but not amazing. Reminded me of a burger. Overall, a solid new addition to the west village!

I was pretty excited to try this place-- it looks cool and the food looks good. Wasn't that hungry so I just got a coffee and a bagel to go. That somehow took 20 minutes even though the place was half empty.Bagel was burnt to a crisp and coffee was too. Staff said sorry, but wasn't that kind about it.

3.5 stars. Semi-curious to try dinner, but I don't quite get the endless rave reviews for brunch alone. PROS: The airy space is lovely and the cute, fabric wall helps to keep the noise level down. The breads and pastries are spot-on. And while I'm usually not a fan of thick-cut pastrami, theirs pulls apart nicely.CONS: Slow service - kept having to wave our waiter down. The waiter recommended the duck meatball sandwich but I was unimpressed - the bread was mushy and while I loved the creativity, the flavor profile fell flat. Also, skip the veggie dishes - nothing to write home about.

This is an awesome spot to go before work, or take a leisurely weekend lunch. Can't speak for times when it's crowded, but in the early morning hours this really is a great spotI had the bodega breakfast sandwich, which I really liked minus the sausage (it was a tad too sweet). Everything else about it was great, though, especially the biscuit.Service is awesome, prices are fair for the area!
Lovely little bakery- just pursued to go pastries rather than sitting down. Walked away with a cute tote, delicious sun butter cake, buckwheat cherry loaf, and good cup of Rival Bros coffee.

Mouthwateringly delicious. Friend and I went all-out in ordering entrees, pastries, and even a dessert--all for brunch and our first meal of the day. I got the duck meatball sub. Yum! The loved the crisp fresh bread that housed the delicious cheesy and tasty meat balls. We got The Forager; loved the mushroom. Affogato for dessert which actually came first which was perfect since it was a nice sweet and bitter coffee pick me up to cleanse our palette. Would definitely come again!

The forager and bodega made me believe in breakfast sandwiches again. The breads are incredible, light fluffy and perfectly held the egg and respective mushroom/sausage in place. I'm in love and will definitely be back to try the rest of the menu.
Great place for a good cup o' joe and a breakfast nosh. Had the Bodega -- gooey, messy, and delicious! Good, dark roast coffee and good service. Great addition to the 'hood.
Ginger yogurt, the Bodega, and Meatball sandwiches were all delicious.

Came in on a Sunday afternoon and surprisingly there was no wait. Here's what we got:- Toast - great assortment of bread and butters. And for $5 can't complain about the value- Forager- lived up to expectations. Add on some of the relish and it was the perfect amount of food mixed with richness - Pastrami and hash- was ok but nothing special to note- Salmon- really great, lighter dishAlso had the Bloody Mary which was solid if not great. Overall great place for a low key brunch and also really affordable.
Food is awesome.  They are new and it shows...need a manager desperately.  Incredible coffee but realky slow to come, our food came before the coffee.  Will try again

This is a great restaurant. The food is creative and well executed, the service is very good, and the price is right. I've not been there for the brunch, but I have had dinner there, and I was very impressed. We all ordered the tasting menu, and presented the server with a combination of dietary restrictions. They were happy to oblige, even when that meant bringing out up to three different versions of the same dish.I can't decide, or maybe better can't recall, which was my favorite dish, but I do remember being consistently impressed, and despite the number of courses, I was never really disappointed in anything I got.I will definitely go back.

Holy cow -- is that a delicious pastrami on rye or what!  This may be my new favorite pastrami, and the bread doesn't fall apart like Katz's.I needed to get out of the office for a proper lunch.  I was seated along the wall and noticed that there were several tables with solo diners reading their papers or phones.  Everyone was allowed to enjoy their meal, and no one was rushed.  Service was very attentive.  I can't wait to return!

I'd come to terms with basic brunch. My brunch criteria has become more about finding a better atmosphere to enjoy my eggs benedict. But then I had the pastrami and hash breakfast sandwich and it has restored my hope in the NYC brunch game.  I'm being a little melodramatic, but this sandwich was really inspiring and messy and delicious. Layers of textures and flavors and an array of sauces and pickles to jazz it up to your liking, all sandwiched between a very pretty poppyseed bun. Served on a cutting board- there isn't anything else you need besides coffee to wash it down. The meatpacker is also a tasty well-rounded plate of food. I found the coppa salty, but that's easily fixed. Take a bit of that with the eggs and broccoli rabe for an excellent bite. The potatoes steal the show, almost halfhazardly broken up with rough edges that increase the surface area = crispy and crunchy all around. Highly recommend arriving early. I waited 30 min at noon on a Saturday. The wait had gone up to an hour around 1pm. The prices are affordable, the brunch ambiance is great, and the service was super friendly.

Cute / Cozy Spot for Lunch - Had the Roast Pork Sandwich , 14. - Very, very good - which was suggested by our server SAM ( Samantha) she is AMAZING!!! ASK FOR HER WHEN YOU COME - I'm such a pain in the bum and she was great -Jefferson - very helpful - got me everything I needed b4 I asked - which was also great since I'm always asking for things Kyle - absolutely fantastic - served our veggies - suggested sides/ and described the dish said he made it - Oh the girl in the front - ehhh We walked in and she said - um, like can you not leave the door open - yikes !!!! Can we get through the door b4 you say anything.

The line was already long on Sunday brunch at noon, although the opening was not so long ago. THE BODEGA ($13) was one of the best Sausage Egg-Chedder Biscuits. It's greasy as McDonald's Sausage Biscuit with Egg and was equally delicious. DUCK MEATBALL SUB ($16) was good too. The meatballs were surprisingly soft and juicy. But lacking in duck flavor was a bit of disappointment. House sparkling water in a cute glass bottle that had good punch of bobbles as Gerolsteiner was fun.It's still new but for busy weekend, having just one person at the front to take care of all the anxious customers seemed to be daunting.

Went to HIgh Street yesterday for lunch. What more is there? Perfection. The beets and feta salad!  I want the recipe. The grilled cheese sandwich and the eggplant sandwich on that great bread was just what the doctor ordered.A-1 wait staff and upfront people who have the hardest jobs in show biz and thanks cooks for a very simple and satisfying meal.

Loved the pastrami & hash breakfast sandwich I ordered. It was a very good sized sandwich. Even though my friend and I wanted to share some pastries afterwards, we were too full to eat more.  Have to come back to try the sumptuous looking pastries next time.  The place is pleasant and our waitress was attentive and very sweet. Was just a lovely experience.

5 stars for freshest bread in the city! Yummy sandwiches and creative pastriesTop notch service - the waitress went out of her way to find the ingredients of each dish, bread. also, despite lines out the door on this windy cold day, we were not rushed to eat or pay--Went for brunch around 11:30am on a Saturday and waited 15 minutes to be seated without a reservation. Delicious pastries- hazelnut fig escargot and spiced donut were standouts. never was i a fan of donuts but this place definitely changed my mind with these yummy popper sized donuts with centers filled with a tad of caramel and custard. kabocha cake was pretty experimental as it was topped with a streusel decorated with candied sage+cardamom For entrees, we got the Forager and asked to sub the roll with anadama miche which perfectly offset the umami flavors of blk truffle mayo+shrooms+eggDuck meatballs were lean and went well mashed between crispy sesame "bing" like bread I've tried breads from the best bakeries : tom cat, maison kayser, orwashers, runner & stone, amy's bread, almondine) but never have I tasted bread so fresh. Don't pass it up if you end up here. I definitely will be back to try roasted potato and cherry rye very soon!

Heard they recently started dinner service so we came here for their Valentine's day pre-fix menu.  Excellent grain, nut, veggie focused menu.  For a couple of meat eaters, we nearly forgotten there was no meat in any dish til the entree!  Most memorable were the rutabaga hummus w/ chimichurri sauce and rye bread tastes like meat loaf w hot sauce!  Then the mushroom wild rice soup was equally awesome as was the sunflower risotto.  I personally like duck but the duck entree was perfect, cooked perfect temperature, skin perfectly smoked and crispy.  Def worth a return trip for their regular dinner menu!

Good edition to the west village Very comfortable , spacious place with beautiful open kitchenThe pastrami on rye was fantastic , everyone needs to buy weekly the rye bread ,its a master!!!They have great innovative pastries , i tried and loved the Meyer lemon cream puff. get few cause its so good.They have more (and very creative) items on the menu , will follow.

Excellent dinner with great wine by the glass (NY state). Sadly, a miserable, negative energy waitress put a drag on the whole experience. It's amazing how little restaurants care or pay attention to this, but it really shapes your impression of a place.  9pm reservation on a Sunday...super quiet, so no excuse for the waitress to be such a downer!

Quick sitting!!! We did the chefs table... Which I love!!! If you like sitting at a bar and watching food being made then you want you wait for it. I got the bodga. Best breakfast sandwich I have ever had. I really want to Order one for later.

..have to update this. Got served a biscuit for breakfast this morning that was basically un-edible. So stale. Went there for lunch today and really enjoyed the experience. Nice room, delicious cappuccino and had the three sides; mushrooms, beets/feta and cauliflower. Was really excellent. The charred eggplant sandwich was a disappointment mainly because I did not ask if eggplant was fried, which it was.. I assumed "charred eggplant" meant it was not fried but this was more my mistake for not asking the question than the dish itself. Definitely recommend
Great fresh food. Awesome unique wine list. Super fun place to come with friends. Cozy.

The "famous" whitefish bagel..........was heated????? dried out warm whitefish on a brown tasteless bagel.Average coffeeGave it three stars as in all fairness thats all I ateshould have sent the warm fishy bagel back..........maybe I ordered wrong??

My first experience with High Street was in Philly and I was blown away. When I heard it was opening in NYC I was so excited and when I went for dinner tonight it did not disappoint. We started with the grilled squid appetizer which came with pistachios, carmelized yogurt and grilled carrots. It was incredible - so flavorful and an amazing combination of textures. We also had the crispy broccoli which was interesting but definitely my least favorite of all the dishes. It has a spicy, pickled Asian taste to it and isn't greasy at all despite being fried. For entrees we had the cauliflower caramelle and I have to be honest - I've eaten an insane amount of pasta in my life and this was one of the absolute best. It was like a soup dumpling filled with cauliflower/cheese purée and the black garlic butter sauce with rosemary was perfect and not overpowering. I cannot recommend this enough. The other main dish we had was the seaweed bucatini. Again, this was a very intricately crafted recipe with truly wonderful textures - every bite had a different element to it. I've never had anything quite like it and I would definitely order it again. For dessert we had the cocoa bean which is cacao mousse, tahini mousse and chocolate crunch with some lemon mixed in there somewhere. It was definitely one of the most unusual desserts I've ever had but it was so delicious. All of that incredible food plus two craft beers and a glass of wine came out to $111 which is honestly very reasonable for the quality of the meal. I can't wait to go back!

I loved this place when I visited their first location in Philadelphia (I went twice on a 3 day visit!), and am so happy we now have an outpost in New York.What more could you want:   - Veggie forward breakfast and lunch options that are fresh, thoughtful and expertly prepared  - Wonderful baked goods and bread baked IN HOUSE with interesting flours and ingredients  - A lovely light-filled corner location in the West Village perfect for brunch or weekday breakfast if you're in the area  - Good coffee!

Group of 6 went for an evening tasting dinner.  Had an amazing time. I appreciated the fact that we were asked right off the bat if anyone had any allergies. I had no allergies but keep a kosher-style diet.  So when they came out with something I could not eat the staff was quick to tell me.Each dish was described in detail to the group, along with why the specific wine was chosen for the pairing. If one of the group felt they did not like a type of wine (too sweet or dry) then a different wine was selected for them.Each dish was amazingly presented. Each dish was delicious and flavorful.  Even something so simple as the bread was amazing.The staff, the food, the restaurant - all were amazing.  I look forward to going back there as soon as possible!Anyone who knows me, knows that I like food.  This restaurant rates a 5 on the Kramer gastro scale! :-)

Came here on Friday night for their new dinner menu, and it was delicious!  We had:House Breads with Spreads- They make their own bread in-house, and you can tell!Razor Clams- Wow, really amazingMushrooms- Very good, but strong onion flavor in the broth, so not recommended if you don't like onionsBucatini- very interesting flavors and textures, unique and tastey, but a little too salty for my palateDuck- the highlight of the meal, perfectly cooked, and I wish there was more!Caraway Rye ice cream- cool flavors, not super sweet, and the candied kumquats make the dish IMOWafer sandwich cookie- got these on our way out, sooooo good!Overall, a really wonderful experience, and I would certainly recommend.  It has a casual rustic feel, great for groups, families, or dates.

Pastries? Amazing.Breakfast sandwiches? Great.Service and wait times? HORRENDOUS. Our first visit to High St on a Saturday morning was no fuss and a wonderful experience. Our server had a bit of an icy attitude but I put that aside because the food, ambiance, decor - everything else was above average. We popped in a second time just to grab pastries and that experience was all well and good also. This morning on other hand has put me off quite a bit. There is an inexplicable gap in the seating process. We were quoted a wait time of 30 minutes and not only were sat after 50 minutes, we were sat after THREE other parties who came after us. And within minutes of another party who arrived well after us. Not to mention during this almost 1 HOUR wait time there were 4-5 WIDE OPEN tables unused with no one seated. Not only that but there was NO remorse or sympathy on the part of the hostesses when they realized the seating error. We stood right by them as they continued to seat other people who arrived after us. We bit our tongues not wanting to cause a scene and I at least hoped to get some sort of empathic comment from one of the two ladies managing the seating but that was wishful thinking. We were finally seated, with no acknowledgement of the wait time or the error.I enjoy the food here and was planning on being a loyal patron but not if this is how every visit is going to go.Come here if you want a good meal but have an hour to kill and don't care if the staff treats you with minimal regard.

What a fantastic new addition to the West Village. All of the breads were made in house and were moist and delicious, especially with the apple-butter and malt-butter they serve them with.I had the pastrami on Rye which was by far the best pastrami I've had in the city (and I've had most of em'), it was cured in house and the rye bread was baked fresh, really fantastic.The rest of my group loved their food as well and the owner was really friendly and came by a lot to make sure we were doing well. Service was great and I ended up buying some bread, pastries and Rival Bros coffee beans at the counter near the front.If you can try and sit at the bar around the side of the open kitchen, its really neat to watch them prep all the food and its essentially a chef's table for two. Looking forward to what they come up with for their dinner menu.

Easily the best breakfast in Manhattan. Can't speak for other times of day, yet... But you should eat here! Breakfast sandwiches are a bit petite but come with a little bottle of jalapeño sauce that is just delicious. The highlight on the much larger breakfast plate was the greens sauteed with ham

Excellent design and decor for the new comer to this great neighborhood. The food, bread, pastry and drink selection is wonderful. Service is provided by a well trained staff that are courteous and knowlegable.

Stopped by on Sunday and was told there would be a bit of a wait. But they do take your number down and contact you when the table is ready. We decided to order at the counter and steal the two bar seats near the coffee stuff to eat our "take out" -- we were not the only ones who did this ha! The forager was very delicious (and vegetarian). Mushrooms were meaty and tasty even though they fell off the sandwich. My boyfriend had the turkey sandwich and said how moist and great it was. Also tasted the Oat cake which was sort of like shortbread with jam in the middle. Want to come back and try the bagels and salads!

Breakfast- Philly style in the West Village. Newly opened, this bakery cum restaurant displays some of the best looking breads since Scratchbread in Brooklyn.Ate & DrankHousemade everything bagel w/ smoked onion cream cheeseChocolate briocheFish kill farms apple ciderRival bros decafThe bagel was almost Montreal/ malt like w/ a mix of flours, it was unusual & exceptional. The brioche was warm-( be still my heart) & rugalah Like. Yum. The cider was sooo fine & tasty & coffee on point. You really can't go wrong with any bread product/pastry at this Philly import.

breakfast: good cappuccino, the brioche with mayer lemon custard is excellent, my favorite. the fig snail it s over decorated with nuts and other useless items that makes it difficult to eat.lunch: great pastrami sandwich at room temperature, great pepper relish at the table.will be back for famous cheese sandwich

"Best new brunch addition in the West Village"Never Been to the Philly spot, but I went here with my Philly born gf on a Sunday brunch exclusion.All was excellent.  From the service to the food that was rich but not over indulgent, this is a great spot. Especially since good, unpretentious spot in this neighborhood is about as rare as a blue zebra.  This is like Le Pain Quotidien with a double upgrade.  Bread is the center, but the carbs are worth it.We had:- Pastrami and Hash, a heavenly mashup of Pastrami, fried potatoes, Russian dressing on a very tasty, flavorful roll.- The Forager, an egg, mushroom, kale, Swiss concoction.- The Grains -- Faro and Squash Salad.  This was the only dish that was just fair.  It had a mushy consistency and lacked a cohesive flavor.- Spiced Donut:  A small, but intense sugared donut with a Carmelesque jelly center.  A perfect way to end the meal!If you are looking for a solid alternative for a brunch spot that is not over the top, you should try it this year!

I can't get over this place. The pastrami sandwich is a must. The broccoli salad is also a must. I don't know if I caught them on a good day or what... But I stumbled in here with my friend in town originally let down that we had settled on a place that wasn't for "foodies" and then we sat down and realized with each bite that this place is going to be big. I feel lucky we only had to wait 20 minutes. We also split the triple sides... And let me tell you, you can't go wrong there either. The pastrami Gods are smiling, and so is everyone else who leaves here. Great, quality, flavorful, beautiful food.

Went here after hearing all the buzz with a friend and it was a wonderful experience from start to finish. There was no wait time as of yet but I'm sure its going to start getting packed.I'll always love breakfast and this place does breakfast justice. My friend ordered the Pastrami and Hash and I ordered The Bodega sandwich and a latte using Rival Brothers Coffee. Lets take sandwich. The Bodega is a sausage, egg, and cheese but where High Street on Hudson succeeds is the sage-pepper biscuit that brings it altogether. Flaky, savory, and buttery and holds up well. There was also a green pepper sauce which you could use and gave the sandwich a great spicy kick. You can also do take out if you so wish though I'd advise to eat the sandwiches right there and then. FRESH. I also got one of the spice doughnuts which is basically a doughnut ball. Not too sweet but a bit on expensive side considering its size. Will definitely come back to try other things on the menu.

Not really for me.Oatmeal was ok, toast had some strange apple butter which didn't work.Seemed a bit chaotic (no menus) but chalk that down to it being new.Cappuccino a pale imitation of what's on offer elsewhere and didn't act as an 'eye opener' Shame, as location is stunning (was always a big fan of cafe cortado before in this location) and it's clear money's been lavishly spent in the refurb and subsequently a nice dining room.It's ok. They're are better places within a stones throw however.

Glad this NYC outpost of the Philly OG finally opened, just in time for the holidays. Staffers at the takeout/pastry/coffee counter at the entrance were friendly but clearly in opening mode. The warmed (forever yet not warm) red eye danish $4.50 was tasty but a bit of a mess...and the cocoa sammie $3.50 was pretty chalky, with nowhere near enough juniper. Beware the too-long, slippery mat near the register..but grab some tasty bread samples.

The new location of the super popular Philly spot is even better than the original, with some great new menu items and a more sensible layout.Now you can peruse and purchase the great pastries from the takeout counter up front, rather than fighting your way through the line to get to the register in the back like in the first location.For breakfast, I tried a few of the great new choices. The Whitefish Bialy ($7.50) is a startlingly black (squid ink) disc topped with whitefish and pickled peppers - definitely a fork and knife deal, and less of a sandwich. The slightly crispy bialy is delicious and goes well with the salty whitefish. Also, The Bodega ($13) is an incredible, rich take on a sausage, egg and cheese. For the bread, an amazing Sage-Black Pepper Biscuit is used, adding even more butteriness to the equation, which is definitely not needed, but still very welcome. These few options make me want to stop off frequently before work, since they are gone at lunchtime (except on the weekends, when they are served along with the brunch menu).On the way out, I picked up some of the pastries (I passed on the Red Eye Danish, but only because I've tried it in Philly, and it is a great choice if you only get one thing). I also tried an Everything Bagel ($2.50), which is not at all like a classic NY bagel, in that it is very small and quite crunchy, but it is really delicious.I will be back very soon for the excellent sandwiches at lunch, such as the Duck Meatball Sub and the Grilled Cheese.

Just came back from brunch, and I feel so satisfied! The staff are warm and inviting. The space has a chic ambience with ample sunlight. I can't wait until this restaurant is open for lunch and dinner. Will definitely be back!
